Justification: We are currently updating the OGD strategy 2019-2024 which will be followed by a master plan 2024-2027. * If yes, please briefly describe the measures.
Guide to Answering: Dynamic data is data that changes asynchronously over time is periodically updated, as new information becomes available. Real-time data is data that changes and needs updating at very frequent intervals, in most cases several times a minute. "The impact of open data on the perception of transparency does not seem to be significant. Our findings show that open data does not increase the transparency of public administrations, which is understood as a continuous process that goes beyond simple data provision. This perception is certainly motivated by the fact that the random release of datasets does not always make them useful or valuable for users (Susha et al., Citation2015). In this sense, it appears crucial to note that open data, if it is to serve the purpose of greater administrative transparency, should be developed in a way that guarantees possible reuse by and empowerment of citizens."
Guide to Answering: The governmental impact is hereby defined as the beneficial effect of the use of open data on three specific challenges faced by the government/public administrations: 1) Being efficient and effective in delivering public services; 2) Being transparent and accountable in their actions; 3) Improving their capacity to make decisions and policies.

Since the beginning of 2023 a new emission calculation model "sonROAD18" became state of the art in Zurich. As of this date, road noise calculations may only be performed using the new model. Also here, the relevant Open Data was included in the relevant process from the beginning, leading to very efficient and effective processes.

Question:
Is there a national extension of the DCAT-AP standard developed for your country? 

For justification:
* If yes, please (1) briefly outline the reasons for this decision, and (2) what the main differences between the national variation and the EU standard are.
* If applicable, please provide the URL to the documentation of the national DCAT-AP extension.
Justification: We have DCAT-AP CH in version 1, which was created in 2018 and builds on DCAT-AP version 1. Version 2.0.0 has recently been approved by eCH. The definition area is https://dcat-ap.ch/. There you will find both versions of the DCAT-AP CH. The portal is mainly based on the DCAT-AP conformance, but also on the version 1 of the DCAT-AP CH, as it contains some Swiss fields used by the community. The decision to create a version 2 of DCAT-AP CH and to keep a national application profile was a difficult one. We decided to keep it because there are particularities in the use of the standard, there are properties such as distribution coverage that the Swiss community relies on and that can't be found in DCAT-AP. The vocabulary also needs Swiss adaptations. Licences are used in a different way than in DCAT-AP. We felt that it would better support the Swiss community if Switzerland maintained its own profile and explained how classes and properties are adapted to the Swiss context. While version 1 of DCAT-AP CH was not DCAT-AP compatible with version 2.0.1 of DCAT-AP. DCAT-AP CH V2 is now compatible with DCAT-AP.

Question:
If yes [to Q124a], what are the main causes for the lack of DCAT-AP compliance?

For justification:
* Please list the most common causes and select 'see answer box'.
Justification: As we are a CKAN portal, the main reason for the lack of DCAT-AP compliance is that as a portal we can't pass through complex data catalogue structures coming from data publishers, even if they are DCAT-AP compliant. We map RDF to postgres on import and postgres to RDF on export. In the process, we lose classes and properties that we don't use on opendata.swiss. What we are trying to do in terms of DCAT-AP compliance is to make our export DCAT-AP compliant as well as making sure that our import is DCAT-AP compliant. But there is still something that gets lost in this internal mapping. A recent example that illustrates this is the categories. We map EU categories, but the portal has Swiss categories implemented. So we might get EU categories from a datapublisher, but because of the mapping to postgres, we would map those categories to Swiss categories and on export to EU categories. His original EU categories will be lost.
